Articles.Content:
Sorry about the newbie questions but this one is bothering me. I saw a video tutorial where the guy was refering to the big notch two thrids of the way up on the throttle as "50 percent" and I was just wondering whether that's correct. Is the throttle more sensitive at lower thrust like that?

Edited July 12, 2014 by qazsedcft

No, the throttle is linear, and directly affects thrust.

(Caveat - Unless he was using a Mod that changes the way throttle or motors fuel flow works)

KSP throttle uses a linear equation to caculate the thrust output; the big notches just divide the throttle in three parts to help you to remember the throttle level easier.

Edited July 12, 2014 by thescientist
This is a common mistake. It really should be 75% since the divisions divide it into 4 parts.
It's not, but I've always wondered why the throttle marks are 33/66/100 instead of 24/50/75/100.
So the guy in the tutorial was wrong. That's what I thought. Not that a logarithmic scale wouldn't make sense, mind you, as usually you want more precision at lower throttle.
